docs.lead_paragraph: Any time David Schiller looks back to the early 1980's, he fondly recalls earning as much as 16 percent interest on the money he was then depositing in the bank. Those were the days, he said, when he could afford to dream of a worry-free retirement in some sunny clime. Mr. Schiller is indeed retired now, and he and his wife, Ruth, own an apartment here. But the 66-year-old New York City native also finds himself working for the minimum wage as a security guard at the entrance to Century Village, a retirement community where he lives, and worrying about the rapid drop in interest rates that has cut drastically into his income.

headline.main: Decline in Interest Rates Gives Retirees the Jitters

docs.snippet: Any time David Schiller looks back to the early 1980's, he fondly recalls earning as much as 16 percent interest on the money he was then depositing in the bank. Those were the days, he said, when he could afford to dream of a worry-free retirement...
